headline.main: Some Countries Are More Social Than Others, Survey Finds

docs.snippet: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can't help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a global survey by Forrester Research, and three out of four write blog pos...
docs.abstract: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can't help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a global survey by Forrester Research, and three out of four write blog posts or upload pictures and music.

headline.main: Some Countries Are More Social Than Others, Survey Finds

docs.snippet: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can't help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a global survey by Forrester Research, and three out of four write blog pos...
docs.abstract: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can't help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a global survey by Forrester Research, and three out of four write blog posts or upload pictures and music.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the big cities of India and China, it seems, people can't help being social. Nearly everyone who uses the Internet there is also active on social networks, according to a vast global survey by Forrester Research, and most of them do much more than read and watch what's posted online. Three out of four of them write blog posts or upload pictures and music.

docs.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission named Pamela A. Gibbs to head its recently created Office of Minority and Women Inclusion, fulfilling a mandate of the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline.main: Today's Wearable Computers Help You Sleep, Not Tweet

docs.snippet: It might be another decade before social network updates flash to us through wearable screens and contact lenses. Yet wearable computing is already here to help people track some aspects of health, like sleep patterns, and view the results through...
docs.abstract: It might be another decade before social network updates flash to us through wearable screens and contact lenses. Yet wearable computing is already here to help people track some aspects of health, like sleep patterns, and view the results through a smartphone.

headline.main: Today's Wearable Computers Help You Sleep, Not Tweet

docs.snippet: It might be another decade before social network updates flash to us through wearable screens and contact lenses. Yet wearable computing is already here to help people track some aspects of health, like sleep patterns, and view the results through...
docs.abstract: It might be another decade before social network updates flash to us through wearable screens and contact lenses. Yet wearable computing is already here to help people track some aspects of health, like sleep patterns, and view the results through a smartphone.
docs.lead_paragraph: I recently wrote a column about wearable computing, in which I discussed a future in which people will eventually wear glasses and contact lenses with built-in screens, delivering content we can use. It will be like having smartphones in our eyes, but much smarter ones.

headline.main: DealBook: With New C.E.O., Yahoo Charts Independent Course

docs.snippet: By naming Scott Thompson as its new chief, the struggling Internet company sent a signal that it intended to try to fix its problems in the public domain, rather than taking itself private. Read more »...
